case_name: State of Bombay & Ors. v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha & Ors.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 712 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE J-URISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 712 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated April 18, 1956 in Appeal No. 65 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 65 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated July 28, 1955,

facts.text: Arising out of Bombay High Court judgment and order dated July 28, 1955 in Misc. Petition No. 113 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated July 28, 1955, of the said High Court is Misc. Petition No. 113 of 1955.

facts.text: Writ petition filed by Hospital Mazdoor Sabha, Mrs. Vatsala Narayan and Mrs. Ruth Isaac against State of Bombay and two others.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the State of Bombay  hereinafter called the appellant  and two others and it arises from a writ petition filed against it by the Hospital Mazdoor Sabha, a trade union registered under the Industrial Trade Unions Act XIV of 1926 and two of its members Mrs. Vatsala Narayan and Mrs. Ruth Isaac  hereinafter called respondents I to 3 .

facts.text: Respondents 2 and 3 were employed as Ward servants in the J.J. group of Hospitals.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents IQ and 3 were employed as Ward servants in the J. J. group of Hospitals.

facts.text: Superintendent of J.J. group of Hospitals issued notices terminating services of respondents 2 and 3 from dates mentioned.

anchor.surface_text: The superintendent of this said group of Hospitals informed the said respondents by numberices issued respectively against them that their services would be terminated with effect from the dates mentioned in the said numberices

facts.text: Services of respondents 2 and 3 were terminated and replaced by two State servants discharged from Civil Supplies Department.

anchor.surface_text: and in accordance with the said numberices their services were in fact terminated subsequently in their place two State servants who were discharged from the Civil Supplies Department were appointed.

facts.text: Retrenchment of respondents 2 and 3 did not comply with ss. 25F and 25H of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition filed by the respondents alleged that the retrenchment of respondents 2 and 3 was void as it did number companyply with the mandatory provisions of ss. 25F and 25H of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  14 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act

facts.text: Tendolkar J. dismissed the writ petition holding orders not void and remedy under s.33(1).

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition was heard by Tendolkar J. The learned judge did number think it necessary to companysider what he called the somewhat ticklish question as to whether the group of Hospitals companystitutes an industry because he held that even assuming that the relevant provisions of the Act were applicable and companyld be invoked by the respondents it was number shown that the impugned orders were void.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Appellate Bench on April 18, 1956 held orders invalid for non-compliance with s.25F and hospitals are industry, allowed writ.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Appeal held that the impugned orders had number companyplied with the mandatory provisions of s. 25F and so they were invalid and inoperative. ... In the result the decision of Tendolkar J. was reversed, the writ petition was allowed and a writ in the nature of mandamus was issued against the appellant.

facts.text: J.J. group consists of five Hospitals.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with these points it would be relevant to state the material facts in regard to the group of Hospitals themselves which are number in dispute. This group companysists of five Hospitals.

facts.text: J.J. Hospitals started in 1835 by Sir Robert Grant for medical education.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1835 Sir Robert Grant, the then Governor of Bombay, desired to start an institution for the purposes of imparting medical education in the Presidency of Bombay.

facts.text: J.J. Hospital formally opened on May 15, 1845.

anchor.surface_text: with which the J. J. Hospital was companystructed and it was formally opened on May 15, 1845.

facts.text: Expenditure on hospitals mostly met by State of Bombay from budget head 38-Medical.

anchor.surface_text: Except for a small amount of Rs. 10,000 the rest of the expenditure which is in the neighbourhood of Rs. 27 lakhs is entirely met by the appellant out of the grant sanctioned in the budget under the bead 38-Medical .

facts.text: Residential staff of hospitals are full-time employees of the State paid monthly.

anchor.surface_text: the residential staff including the Resident Medical Officers, Assistant Medical Officers, Housemen, Nurses and others are all full-time employees of the -appellant and their salaries are drawn on the establishment pay bills every month and paid entirely by the appellant.

facts.text: Hospitals serve as clinical training ground for Grant Medical College students.

anchor.surface_text: This group serves as a clinical training ground for students of the Grant Medical College which is a Government Medical College run and . managed by the appellant

facts.text: Services of respondents 2 and 3 retrenched without paying compensation under s.25F(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that the said respondents had number been paid at the time of retrenchment companypensation as prescribed by s. 25F b .

facts.text: Respondents 2 and 3 had continuous service for not less than one year.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25F  b  provides that numberworkman employed III in any industry who has been in companytinuous service for number less than one year under an employer

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 29, 1960 by Gajendragadkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. January 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held J.J. group of Hospitals is an industry under s.2(j) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The activities which do number fall within s. 2 j  and which are described as governmental or regal or sovereign have been pithily described by Lord Watson as the primary and inalienable functions of a companystitutional Government  Vide Coomber v. Justices of Berks 1    and it is only these activities that are outside the scope of s. 2 j . It sounds incongruous and self- companytradictory  1   1883  App. cas. 61.

precedents.cited_proposition: primary and inalienable functions of a constitutional Government are regal or sovereign activities

anchor.surface_text: In D. N. Banerji v. P. R. Mukherjee Ors.  1 , this Court was dealing with a a industrial dispute raised by the Municipal Workers Union of the Budge Budge Municipality, on behalf of the Sanitary Inspector and Head Clerk of the said Municipality on the ground that the dismissal of the said two Municipal employees was unjustified and  1 1953 S.C.R. 302. illegal, and that they were entitled to an order of reinstatement.

precedents.case_name: D N Banerji v P R Mukherjee
precedents.cited_proposition: municipal activities analogous to trade or business constitute industry under s 2(j); absence of profit motive or capital investment not essential
precedents.cited_holding: the definitions in our Act include also disputes that might arise between municipalities and their employees in branches of work that can be said to be analogous to the carrying out of a trade or business

anchor.surface_text: This decision has been referred to by this, Court in Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen  1 , and it has been observed that it is number finally settled that a municipal undertaking of the nature with which the companyrt was then companycerned is an industry within the meaning of the definition of that word in s. 2 j  of the Act  1 1957 S.C.R. 33.

precedents.case_name: Baroda Borough Municipality v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: municipal undertakings analogous to trade or business are industry

anchor.surface_text: In  1 1952 II L.L.J. 327. Sri Vishuddhananda Saraswathi Marwari Hospital v. Their Workmen  1  the, Labour Appellate Tribunal companysidered at length the policy and object of the Act, several judgments cited before it and came to the companyclusion that the definition of industry in s. 2 j  was of wide amplitude and that there was numbergood reason for cutting down its natural meaning so as to limit its operation to profit-making enterprises only.

precedents.case_name: Sri Vishuddhananda Saraswathi Marwari Hospital v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: hospital is an undertaking within the meaning of s 2(j)

anchor.surface_text: In judicial discussions about the scope and character of the companycept of industry as it has developed in a modern democratic State the decision of the High Court of Australia in The Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia And The State of Victoria Ors  2 , is generally cited. In that case, according to the majority decision it was held that the educational activities of the State carried on under the appropriate statutes  2  1929 4 C.L.R. 569.

precedents.case_name: Federated State School Teachers Association of Australia v State of Victoria
precedents.cited_proposition: characteristics of industrial enterprises and disputes; true character of activity determines if industry
precedents.cited_holding: industrial disputes occur when in relation to operations in which capital and labour are contributed in cooperation for the satisfaction of human wants or desires, those engaged in cooperation dispute as to basis to be observed by the parties engaged

precedents.case_name: Brij Mohan Bagaria v NC Chatterjee
precedents.cited_proposition: individual liberal profession like attorney dependent on personal skill not industry
precedents.cited_holding: however extended the meaning be given to the word industry or to industrial dispute or to undertaking or calling we cannot include within their concept the case of an individual who carries on a profession dependent upon its own intellectual skill

precedents.citation: National Union of Commercial Employees Anr. And Meher R. Ors. Pereira Fazalbhoy Co.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with a similar case of an attorney, the Bombay High Court has taken the same view in National Union of Commercial Employees Anr. And Meher R.  Ors.  Pereira Fazalbhoy Co.   1 . We would accordingly bold that the High Court was right in holding that the dispute between the appellant and the respondents was an industrial dispute to which s. 251 of the Act applied.
